text:
When I use <env> to set the PATH for a junit task on XP, it doesn't take. ant -
v shows the setting, but the JVM does not find the DLLS. I will attach two 
runs, one failing using <env> and one succeeding PATH setup in the command 
window environment before the run.
creator: benson@basistech.com
benson@basistech.com
text:
Created attachment 3911
script of a failure resulting from not finding a JNI dll in spite of setting PATH in <env>

Created attachment 3912
run that succeeds due to setting PATH at command level before running ant
creator: benson@basistech.com

text:
This is interesting, you are running java1.4 and the first attachment clearly
shows that you are setting both path and the sysproperty java.library.path. 

Note that java.library.path that only works (in windows) for one level of
inclusion: DLLs the JNI DLL load wont get found, which is a bug in the JVM (they
use the wrong version of ::LoadLibary. Is this what you are trying to do?
creator: stevel@apache.org

text:
Yes.

I am setting path precisely in order to get around the fact that 
java.library.path is not helpful for dependent libraries on Windows in 1.4.

I might as well take the second path out of java.library.path, but I left it 
as a comment pointing toward some future time when the JVM might do the right 
thing.

I picked up 1.5.1 specifically because I thought that <env> would allow me to 
stop needing to set PATH in the environment outside of ant to make this work.
creator: benson@basistech.com

text:
These PATH issues with Ant on windows are troublesome. Be sure to use the same 
capitalization everywhere. I finally diagnosed a problem a colleague was 
haven't to the fact she had 'path' defined instead of 'Path'. For DOS, it 
doesn't matter, but it does for Ant, or more precisely for the apps forked 
using Ant (msdev.exe in my case). Furthmore, it seems you need to fully unset 
the path and reset it to be able to change its capitalization (on Win2K at 
least). Very weird, --DD
